revision.comment: add three references appropriate for article and future inline citations, delete Linedecker book, not cited and not necessary for complete citations
revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |name= William Edwin Baldwin |birth_date= {{birth date|1827|7|28}} |death_date= {{death date and age|1864|2|19|1827|7|28}} |image= WEBaldwin.jpg |caption= |nickname= |birth_place= Mississippi, United States |death_place= Mobile County, Alabama |placeofburial= |placeofburial_label= Place of burial |allegiance=
{{flagicon|CSA|1864}} [[Confederate States of America]] |branch= {{army|CSA}} |serviceyears= 1861–64 |rank= [[File:Confederate_States_of_America_General-collar.svg|35px]] [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] |unit= |commands={{Flagicon|Mississippi|1861}} 14th Mississippi Infantry |battles= [[American Civil War]]
- [[Battle of Fort Donelson]]
- [[Battle of Coffeeville]]
- [[Battle of Port Gibson]]
- [[Battle of Champion's Hill]]
- [[Vicksburg Campaign]] |awards= |relations= |laterwork= }} '''William Edwin Baldwin''' (July 28, 1827 – February 19, 1864) was a [[Confederate States Army|Confederate Army]] officer during the [[American Civil War]]. A bookstore owner and member of the local [[militia]] in [[Columbus, Mississippi]], Baldwin enlisted in the Confederate Army soon after [[Mississippi]] announced its [[secession]] from the [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]], accepting a commission as [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] of the [[14th Mississippi Infantry]] Regiment. Stationed briefly in [[Pensacola, Florida]], he was transferred with his unit to [[East Tennessee]] and later central [[Kentucky]], where he fought and was later captured at the [[Battle of Fort Donelson]]. After being released in a prisoner exchange, he was promoted to the rank of [[History of Confederate States Army Generals#Brigadier general|brigadier general]] and sent to [[West Tennessee]], where he assumed command of a mixed [[brigade]] of Mississippi and Tennessee soldiers. Winning distinction at the [[Battle of Coffeeville]], Baldwin would later participate in the battles of [[Battle of Port Gibson|Port Gibson]] and [[Battle of Champion's Hill|Champion's Hill]], as well as taking part in the [[Vicksburg Campaign]]. Captured once again, Baldwin was able to secure his release and assigned to the [[District of Mobile]] where he was killed in an accident when a broken stirrup caused him to fall off his horse, near the [[Dog River (Alabama)|Dog River]] in Alabama. ==See also== {{portal|American Civil War|Biography}} *[[List of American Civil War generals (Confederate)]] ==References== * Eicher, John H., and [[David J. Eicher]], ''Civil War High Commands.'' Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2001. ISBN 978-0-8047-3641-1. * Sifakis, Stewart. ''Who Was Who in the Civil War.'' New York: Facts On File, 1988. ISBN 978-0-8160-1055-4. * [[Ezra J. Warner (historian)|Warner, Ezra J.]] ''Generals in Gray: Lives of the Confederate Commanders.'' Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1959. ISBN 978-0-8071-0823-9. {{DEFAULTSORT:Baldwin, William E.}} [[Category:1827 births]] [[Category:1864 deaths]] [[Category:Confederate States Army generals]] [[Category:People of Mississippi in the American Civil War]] [[Category:American Civil War prisoners of war]] [[Category:People from Columbus, Mississippi]]
